The hands of the Dutch clock in the hall pointed to thirteen minutes past nine; those of the ormolu clock in the sitting-room to eleven minutes past ten; those of the carriage clock on the bookshelf to fourteen minutes to six. In other words, it was exactly eight; and Mrs. Hignett acknowledged the fact by moving her head on the pillow, opening her eyes, and sitting up in bed. She always woke at eight precisely.
17:46.author: P.G. Wodehouse

17:48.quote: Father came home at 5:48 p.m. I heard him come through the front door. Then he came into the living room. He was wearing a lime green and sky blue check shirt and there was a double knot on one of his shoes but not on the other.
17:48.book: The Curious Incident Of The Dog In The Night-Time
17:48.author: Mark Haddon

17:50.quote: """What time is it Jack?"" ""Ten to six""""Ten more minutes then."" I shuffle the cards. ""Time for a quick game of rummy?"""
17:50.author: Malorie Blackman

17:53.quote: """That boy will be spoiled, as sure as I go on springs; he's made such a lot of. Have you been regulated?"" ""I should think I have!"" exclaimed I, in indignant recollection of my education. ""All right; keep your temper. What time are you?"" ""Seven minutes to six."""
17:53.book: The Adventures of a Three-Guinea Watch
17:53.author: Talbot Baines Reed

17:54.quote: "It was 5:54 pm when Father came back into the living room. He said, 'What is this?"" but he said it very quietly and I didn't realise that he was angry because he wasn't shouting."
17:54.book: The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-time
17:54.author: Mark Haddon

17:55.quote: The wind moaned and sang dismally, catching the ears and lifting the shabby coat-tails of Mr Mortimer Jenkyn, 'Photographic Artist', as he stood outside and put the shutters up with this own cold hands in despair of further trade. It was five minutes to six.
17:55.author: Algernon Blackwood

17:57.quote: When he arrived it was nearly six o'clock, and the sun was setting full and warm, and the red light streamed in through the window and gave more colour to the pale cheeks.
17:57.author: Bram Stoker

17:58.quote: It was nearly six o'clock in the evening, and the absurd bell in the six-foot tin steeple of the church went clank-clank, clank- clank! as old Mattu pulled the rope within.'
17:58.author: George Orwell

17:59.quote: When he arrived it was nearly six o'clock, and the sun was setting full and warm, and the red light streamed in through the window and gave more colour to the pale cheeks.
17:59.author: Bram Stoker

18:00.book: The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-time
18:00.author: Mark Haddon

18:00.quote: Although it was only six o'clock, the night was already dark. The fog, made thicker by its proximity to the Seine, blurred every detail with its ragged veils, punctured at various distances by the reddish glow of lanterns and bars of light escaping from illuminated windows.
18:00.author: ThÃ©ophile Gautier

18:00.quote: Did you go down to the farm while I was away?' 'No,' I said 'but I saw Ted.' 'Did he have a message for me ?' she asked. 'He said today was no good as he was going to Norwich. But Friday at six o'clock, same as usual.' 'Are you sure he said six o'clock?' she asked, puzzled. 'Quite sure.'
18:00.author: L.P. Hartley

18:00.quote: King Richard: What is o'clock? Catesby: It is six o'clock, full supper time. King Richard: I will not sup tonight. Give me some ink and paper.
18:00.author: William Shakespeare

18:00.quote: Leon waited all day for six o'clock to arrive; when he got to the inn, he found no one there but Monsieur Binet, already at the table.
18:00.author: Gustave Flaubert

18:00.quote: Oh oh oh. Six o'clock and the master not home yet.
18:00.author: Thornton Wilder

18:00.quote: The newspaper snaked through the door and there was suddenly a six o'clock feeling in the house
18:00.book: The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie
18:00.author: Muriel Spark

18:00.quote: The winter evening settles down With smell of steaks in passageways. Six o'clock.
18:00.author: T S Eliot

18:00.quote: When the bells of Calvary Church struck six, she saw Mr and Mrs Biggs hurrying down the front stoop, rushing off to the shops before they closed.
18:00.author: Jed Rubenfeld

18:03.quote: Above it all rose the Houses of Parliament, with the hands of the clock stopped at three minutes past six. It was difficult to believe that all that meant nothing any more, that now it was just a pretentious confection that could decay in peace.
18:03.author: John Wyndham

18:04.quote: """We will make record of it, my Rosannah; every year, as this dear hour chimes from the clock, we will celebrate it with thanksgivings, all the years of our life."" ""We will, we will, Alonzo!"" ""Four minutes after six, in the evening, my Rosannah...â"
18:04.book: The Loves of Alonzo Fitz Clarence and Rosannah Ethelton
18:04.author: Mark Twain

18:05.quote: At about five past six Piers came in carrying an evening paper and a few books.
18:05.author: Barbara Pym

18:08.quote: "6:08 p.m. The code-word ""Valkyrie"" reached von Seydlitz Gabler's headquarters"
18:08.author: Hans Hellmut Kirst

18:10.quote: 'Let me see now. You had a drink at the Continental at six ten.' 'Yes.' 'And at six forty-five you were talking to another journalist at the door of the Majestic?' 'Yes, Wilkins. I told you all this, Vigot, before. That night.'
18:10.author: Graham Greene

18:15.quote: 'Quarter past six,' said Tony. 'He's bound to have told her by now.'
18:15.author: Evelyn Waugh

18:15.quote: At a quarter past six he was through with them.
18:15.author: Penelope Lively

18:15.quote: I checked the time on the corner of my screen. 6.15 pm. I was never going to finisah my essay in forty-five minutes
18:15.author: Sophie McKenzie

18:20.quote: By the time Elliot's mother arrived at twenty past six, Mrs Sen always made sure all evidence of her chopping was disposed of.
18:20.author: Jhumpa Lahiri

18:21.quote: 5.20pm - 6.21pm: Miss Pettigrew found herself wafted into the passage. She was past remonstrance now, past bewilderment, surprise, expostulation. Her eyes shone. Her face glowed. Her spirits soared. Everything was happening too quickly. She couldn't keep up with things, but, by golly, she could enjoy them.
18:21.book: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day
18:21.author: Winifred Watson

18:22.quote: Clock overturned when he fell forward. That'll give us the time of the crime. Twenty-two minutes past six.
18:22.author: Agatha Christie

18:25.quote: At twenty-five past six I go into the bathroom and have a wash, then while the Old Lady's busy in the kitchen helping Chris with the washing up I get my coat and nip out down the stairs.
18:25.author: Stan Barstow

18:25.quote: I have this moment, while writing, had a wire from Jonathan saying that he leaves by the 6.25 tonight from Launceston and will be here at 10.18, so that I shall have no fear tonight.
18:25.author: Bram Stoker

18:26.quote: It is around half past six in the evening. Dusk is gathering in the living room, an early dusk due to the fog which has rolled in from the Sound and is like a white curtain drawn down outside the windows.
18:26.author: Eugene O'Neill

18:30.quote: At six-thirty I left the bar and walked outside. It was getting dark and the big Avenida looked cool and graceful. On the other side were homes that once looked out on the beach. Now they looked out on hotels and most of them had retreated behind tall hedges and walls that cut them off from the street.
18:30.author: Hunter S. Thompson

18:30.quote: 6.30 p.m. Watch television or a video
18:30.book: The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-time
18:30.author: Mark Haddon

18:30.quote: As I was turning away, grieved to be parting from him, a thought started up in me and I turned back. 'Shall I take one more message for you?' 'That's good of you' he said, 'but do you want to?' 'Yes, just this once.' It could do no harm, I thought; and I should be far away when the message takes effect, and I wanted to say something to show we were friends. 'Well,' he said, once more across the gap, 'say tomorrow's no good, I'm going to Norwich, but Friday at half-past six, same as usual.'
18:30.author: L.P. Hartley

18:30.quote: At five o'clock the two ladies retired to dress, and at half past six Elizabeth was summoned to dinner.
18:30.author: Jane Austen

18:30.quote: It is six thirty. Now the dark night and the deafening racket of the crickets again engulf the garden and the veranda, all around the house
18:30.author: Alain Robbe-Grillet

18:30.quote: To a casual visitor it might have seemed that Mr Penicuik, who owned the house, had fallen upon evil days; but two of the three gentlemen assembled in the Saloon at half-past six on a wintry evening of late February were in no danger of falling into this error.
18:30.author: Georgette Heyer

18:31.quote: I had been delayed at a case and it was a little after half past six when I found myself at Baker Street once more
18:31.timeAlt: a little after half past six
18:31.book: The Adventure of The Blue Carbuncle
18:31.author: Arthur Conan Doyle

18:32.quote: It is around half past six in the evening. Dusk is gathering in the living room, an early dusk due to the fog which has rolled in from the Sound and is like a white curtain drawn down outside the windows.
18:32.author: Eugene O'Neill

18:33.quote: Every evening, Michel took the train home, changed at Esbly and usually arrived in CrÃ©cy on the 6.33pm train where Annabelle would be waiting at the station.
18:33.author: Michel Houellebecq

18:34.quote: It is around half past six in the evening. Dusk is gathering in the living room, an early dusk due to the fog which has rolled in from the Sound and is like a white curtain drawn down outside the windows.
18:34.author: Eugene O'Neill

18:35.quote: And then it was 6.35 pm and I heard Father come home in his van and I moved the bed up against the door so he couldn't get in and he came into the house and he and Mother shouted at each other.
18:35.book: The Curious Incident Of The Dog In The Night-Time
18:35.author: Mark Haddon

18:36.quote: Kaldren pursues me like luminescent shadow. He has chalked up on the gateway '96,688,365,498,702'. Should confuse the mail man. Woke 9:05. To sleep 6:36.
18:36.author: JG Ballard

18:40.quote: Amy: What's that? I thought I saw someone pass the window. What time is it? Charles: Nearly twenty to seven.
18:40.author: TS Eliot

18:40.quote: Having to change 'buses, I allowed plenty of time â in fact, too much; for we arrived at twenty minutes to seven, and Franching, so the servant said, had only just gone up to dress.
18:40.author: George and Weedon Grossmith

18:41.quote: He made it to Grand Central well in advance. Stillman's train was not due to arrive until six forty-one, but Quinn wanted time to study the geography of the place, to make sure that Stillman would not be able to slip away from him.
18:41.author: Paul Auster

18:45.quote: 'Let me see now. You had a drink at the Continental at six ten.' 'Yes.' 'And at six forty-five you were talking to another journalist at the door of the Majestic?' 'Yes, Wilkins. I told you all this, Vigot, before. That night.'
18:45.author: Graham Greene

18:45.quote: """Six forty-five,"" called Louie. ""Did you hear, Ming,"" he asked, ""did you hear?"" ""Yes, Taddy, I heard."" ""What is it?' asked Tommy. ""The new baby, listen, the new baby."""
18:45.author: Christina Stead

18:45.quote: It was a quarter to seven when I let myself into the office and clicked the light on and picked a piece of paper off the floor. It was a notice from the Green Feather Messenger Service ...
18:45.author: Raymond Chandler

18:49.quote: 6:49 p.m. Lieutenant-General Tanz escorted by a motorized unit, drove to Corps headquarters
18:49.author: Hans Hellmut Kirst

18:50.quote: At ten minutes to seven Dulcie was ready. She looked at herself in the wrinkly mirror. The reflection was satisfactory. The dark blue dress, fitting without a wrinkle, the hat with its jaunty black feather, the but-slightly-soiled gloves--all representing self- denial, even of food itself--were vastly becoming. Dulcie forgot everything else for a moment except that she was beautiful, and that life was about to lift a corner of its mysterious veil for her to observe its wonders. No gentleman had ever asked her out before. Now she was going for a brief moment into the glitter and exalted show.
18:50.author: O. Henry

18:50.quote: It was time to go see the Lady. When we arrived at her house at ten minutes before seven o'clock, Damaronde answered the door.
18:50.author: Robert R. McCammon

18:50.quote: It was time to go see the Lady. When we arrived at her house at ten minutes before seven o'clock, Damaronde answered the door.
18:50.author: Robert R. McCammon

18:51.quote: The square of light in the kitchen doorway had faded to thin purple; his watch said 6:51.
18:51.author: Stephen King

18:53.quote: It was near on seven o'clock when I got to Mr. and Mrs. Fleming's house on 6th Street, where I was renting a room. It was late September, and though there was some sun left, I didn't want to visit a dead man's place with night coming on.
18:53.author: Edward P Jones

18:55.quote: "... You had no reason to think the times important. Indeed how suspicious it would be if you had been completely accurate. ''Haven't I been?'' Not quite. It was five to seven that you talked to Wilkins. ''Another ten minutes."""
18:55.author: Graham Greene

18:55.quote: The play was set to begin at seven o'clock and finish before sunset. It was 6:55. Beyond the flats we could hear the hockey field filling up. the low rumble got steadily louder - voices, footsteps, the creaking of bleachers, the slamming of car doors in the parking lot.
18:55.author: Jeffrey Eugenides

18:56.quote: Then it was 6.56. A black Rover - a Rover 90, registration PYX 520 - turned into the street that ran down the left-hand side of The Bunker. It parked. The door on the driver's side opened. A man got out.
18:56.author: Rupert Thomson

18:57.quote: """I feel a little awkward,"" Kay Randall said on the phone, ""asking a man to do these errands ... but that's my problem, not yours. Just bring the supplies and try to be at the church meeting room a few minutes before seven."""
18:57.author: Max Apple

18:57.quote: Folded in this triple melody, the audience sat gazing; and beheld gently and approvingly without interrogation, for it seemed inevitable, a box tree in a green tub take the place of the ladiesâ dressing-room; while on what seemed to be a wall, was hung a great clock face; the hands pointing to three minutes to the hour; which was seven.'
18:57.timeAlt: three minutes to the hour; which was seven
18:57.author: Virginia Woolf

18:58.quote: """Walk fast,"" says Perry, ""it's two minutes to seven, and I got to be home byâ' ""Oh, shut up,"" says I. ""I had an appointment as chief performer at an inquest at seven, and I'm not kicking about not keeping it."""
18:58.author: O. Henry

18:59.quote: About seven oâclock in the evening she had died, and her frantic husband had made a frightful scene in his efforts to kill West, whom he wildly blamed for not saving her life. Friends had held him when he drew a stiletto, but West departed amidst his inhuman shrieks, curses, and oaths of vengeance.
18:59.author: H. P. Lovecraft

19:00.quote: â¦ in a word, seen always at the same evening hour, isolated from all its possible surroundings, detached and solitary against its shadowy background, the bare minimum of scenery necessary .. to the drama of my undressing, as though all Combray had consisted of but two floors joined by a slender staircase, and as though there had been no time there but seven o'clock at night.
19:00.book: In Search of Lost Time: Swann's Way
19:00.author: Marcel Proust

19:00.quote: The town clock struck seven. The echoes of the great chime wandered in the unlit halls of the library. An autumn leaf, very crisp, fell somewhere in the dark. But it was only the page of a book, turning.
19:00.author: Ray Bradbury

19:00.book: The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-time
19:00.author: Mark Haddon

19:00.quote: By seven o'clock the orchestra has arrived--no thin five-piece affair but a whole pitful of oboes and trombones and saxophones and viols and cornets and piccolos and low and high drums.
19:00.author: F. Scott Fitzgerald

19:00.quote: Edward had been allowed to see me only from seven till nine-thirty pm, always inside the confines of my home and under the supervision of my dad's unfailingly crabby glare.
19:00.author: Stephenie Meyer

19:00.quote: It was seven o'clock and by this time she was not very far from Raveloe, but she was not familiar enough with those monotonous lanes to know how near she was to her journey's end. She needed comfort, and she knew but one comforter - the familiar demon in her bosom; but she hesitated a moment, after drawing out the black remnant, before she raised it to her lips.
19:00.author: George Eliot

19:00.quote: It was seven o'clock when we got into the coupÃ© with him and started for Long Island. [...] So we drove on toward death through the cooling twilight.
19:00.author: F. Scott Fitzgerald

19:01.quote: He waited until nearly eight, because around seven there were always more people coming in and out of the house than at other times.
19:01.author: Patricia Highsmith

19:02.quote: Twas about seven o'clock at night, And the wind it blew with all its might, And the rain came pouring down, And the dark clouds seem'd to frown,
19:02.author: William McGonagall

19:08.quote: It was eight minutes past seven and still no girl. I waited impatiently. I watched another crowd surge through the barriers and move quickly down the steps. My eyes were alert for the faintest recognition.
19:08.author: James Furner

19:10.quote: He had already got to the point where, by rocking more strongly, he maintained his equilibrium with difficulty, and very soon he would finally have to make a final decision, for in five minutes it would be a quarter past seven. Then there was a ring at the door of the apartment. âThatâs someone from the office,â he told himself, and he almost froze, while his small limbs only danced around all the faster. For one moment everything remained still. âThey arenât opening,â Gregor said to himself, caught up in some absurd hope.
19:10.timeAlt: in five minutes it would be a quarter past seven
19:10.author: Franz Kafka

19:10.quote: The party was to begin at seven. The invitations gave the hour as six-thirty because the family knew everyone would come a little late, so as not to be the first to arrive. At seven-ten not a soul had come; somewhat acrimoniously, the family discussed the advantages and disadvantages of tardiness
19:10.author: Jorge Luis Borges

19:11.quote: Good, you said. Run, or you won't get a seat. See you soon. Your voice was reassuring. 19:11:00, the clock said. I put the phone back on its hook and I ran. The seat I got, almost the last one in the carriage, was opposite a girl who started coughing as soon as there weren't any other free seats I could move to. She looked pale and the cough rattled deep in her chest as she punched numbers into her mobile. Hi, she said (cough). I'm on the train. No, I've got a cold. A cold (cough). Yeah, really bad. Yeah, awful actually. Hello? (cough) Hello?
19:11.book: The Whole Story and Other Stories
19:11.author: Ali Smith

19:12.quote: "He taught me that if I had to meet someone for an appointment, I must refuse to follow the 'stupid human habit' of arbitrarily choosing a time based on fifteen-minute intervals. ""Never meet people at 7:45 or 6:30, Jasper, but pick times like 7:12 and 8:03!"""
19:12.author: Steve Toltz

19:14.quote: If he'd lived in New York and worked in an office, he might have thrived as the typical, over-martini'd, cheating husband, leaving every night on the 7:14 to White Plains, a smudge of lipstick high on his neck, and a tide of lies to see him through to the next day.
19:14.book: The Life and Opinions of Maf the Dog, and of his friend Marilyn Monroe
19:14.author: Andrew O'Hagan

19:15.quote: Cell count down to 400,000. Woke 8:10. To sleep 7:15. (Appear to have lost my watch without realising it, had to drive into town to buy another.)
19:15.author: JG Ballard

19:15.quote: Nick had a large wild plan of his own for the night, but for now he let Leo take charge: they were going to go back to Notting Hill and catch the seven fifteen screening of Scarface at the Gate.
19:15.author: Alan Hollinghurst

19:15.quote: The party was to begin at seven. The invitations gave the hour as six-thirty because the famly knew everyone would come a little late, so as not to be the first to arrive. .. By seven-fifteen not another soul could squeeze into the house.
19:15.author: Jorge Luis Borges

19:16.quote: âSixteen past seven PM? That's when he came into the store or when he left after the fact?â
19:16.author: Patricia Cornwell

19:17.quote: Colonel Putnis knocked on his door at 7.17 p.m. The car was waiting in front of the hotel, and they drove through the dark streets to police headquarters. It had grown much colder during the evening, and the city was almost deserted.
19:17.author: Henning Mankell

19:19.quote: And it was me who spent about three hours this afternoon arguing one single contract. The term was best endeavors. The other side wanted to use reasonable efforts. In the end we won the point- but I can't feel my usual triumph. All I know is, it's seven-nineteen, and in eleven minutes I'm supposed to be halfway across town, sitting down to dinner at Maxim's with my mother and brother Daniel. I'll have to cancel. My own birthday dinner.
19:19.author: Sophie Kinsella

19:20.quote: The clock read seven-twenty, but I felt no hunger. You'd think I might have wanted to eat something after the day I'd had, but I cringed at the very thought of food. I was short of sleep, my gut was slashed, and my apartment was gutted. There was no room for appetite.
19:20.book: Hard Boiled Wonderland and the End of the World
19:20.author: Haruki Murakami

19:20.quote: The pause, we finally concluded, was to allow the other important people to catch up, those who had arrived at 7:10 waiting for those who had arrived at 7:20.
19:20.book: Parkinson's Law or the Pursuit of Progress
19:20.author: C Northcote Parkinson

19:21.quote: Gripping her gym bag in her right hand, Aomame, like Buzzcut, was waiting for something to happen. The clock display changed to 7:21, then 7:22, then 7:23.
19:21.author: Haruki Murakami

19:22.quote: Gripping her gym bag in her right hand, Aomame, like Buzzcut, was waiting for something to happen. The clock display changed to 7:21, then 7:22, then 7:23.
19:22.author: Haruki Murakami

19:23.quote: Gripping her gym bag in her right hand, Aomame, like Buzzcut, was waiting for something to happen. The clock display changed to 7:21, then 7:22, then 7:23.
19:23.author: Haruki Murakami

19:24.quote: He picked up his hat and coat and Clarice said hello to him and he said hello and looked at the clock and it was almost twenty-five after seven.
19:24.author: James Thurber

19:25.quote: He picked up his hat and coat and Clarice said hello to him and he said hello and looked at the clock and it was almost twenty-five after seven.
19:25.author: James Thurber

19:30.quote: But now he was close - here was the house, here were the gates. Somewhere a clock beat a single chime. 'What, is it really half-past seven? That's impossible, it must be fast!â
19:30.author: Fyodor Dostoyevsky

19:30.quote: On July 25th, 8:30 a.m. the bitch Novaya dies whelping. At 10 o'clock she is lowered into her cool grave, at 7:30 that same evening we see our first floes and greet them wishing they were the last.
19:30.book: The Terrors of Ice and Darkness
19:30.author: Christoph Ransmayr

19:30.quote: The clock showed half-past seven. This was the twilight time. He would be there now. I pictured him in his old navy-blue sweater and peaked cap, walking soft-footed up the track towards the wood. He told me he wore the sweater because navy-blue barely showed up in the dark, black was even better, he said. The peaked cap was important too, he explained, because the peak casts a shadow over one's face.
19:30.book: Danny, the Champion of the World
19:30.author: Roald Dahl

19:30.quote: The telephone call came at 7.30 on the evening of March 18th, a Saturday, the eve of the noisy, colourful festival that the town held in honour of Saint Joseph the carpenter -
19:30.author: Leonardo Sciascia

19:35.quote: 7.35-40. Yseut arrives at 'M. and S.', puts through phone call.
19:35.book: The Case of the Gilded Fly
19:35.author: Edmund Crispin

19:40.quote: She arrives at 7.40, ten minutes late, but the children, Jimmy and Bitsy, are still eating supper and their parents are not ready to go yet. From other rooms come the sound of a baby screaming, water running, a television musical (no words: probably a dance number - patterns of gliding figures come to mind).
19:40.author: Robert Coover

19:42.quote: I glance at my watch as we speed along the Strand. Seven forty-two. I'm starting to feel quite excited. The street outside is still bright and warm and tourists are walking along in T-shirts and shorts, pointing at the High Court. It must have been a gorgeous summer's day. Inside the air-conditioned Carter Spink building you have no idea what the weather in the real world is doing.
19:42.author: Sophie Kinsella

19:45.quote: "He taught me that if I had to meet someone for an appointment, I must refuse to follow the 'stupid human habit' of arbitrarily choosing a time based on fifteen-minute intervals. ""Never meet people at 7:45 or 6:30, Jasper, but pick times like 7:12 and 8:03!"""
19:45.author: Steve Toltz

19:45.quote: "He tells his old friend the train times and they settle on the 19.45 arriving at 23.27. 'I'll book us into the ultra-luxurious Francis Drake Lodge. Running water in several rooms. Have you got a mobile?"""
19:45.author: Justin Cartwright

19:49.quote: "There's a big, old-fashioned clock in the surgery. Just as Dr. Wellesley went out I heard the Moot Hall clock chime half-past seven, and then the chimes of St. Hathelswide's Church. I noticed that our clock was a couple of minutes slow, and I put it right."" When did you next see Dr. Wellesley?"" ""At just eleven minutes to eight."" ""Where?"" ""In the surgery."" ""He came back there?"" ""Yes."" ""How do you fix that precise time--eleven minutes to eight?"" ""Because he'd arranged to see a patient in Meadow Gate at ten minutes to eight. I glanced at the clock as he came in, saw what time it was, and reminded him of the appointment."""
19:49.author: J. S. Fletcher

19:50.quote: At ten to eight, he strolled downstairs, to make sure that Signora Buffi was not pottering around in the hall and that her door was not open, and to make sure there really was no one in Freddie's car
19:50.author: Patricia Highsmith

19:52.quote: He waited until nearly eight, because around seven there were always more people coming in and out of the house than at other times. At ten to eight, he strolled downstairs, to make sure that Signora Buffi was not pottering around in the hall and that her door was not open, and to make sure there really was no one in Freddie's car, though he had gone down in the middle of the afternoon to look at the car and see if it was Freddie's.
19:52.author: Patricia Highsmith

19:53.quote: "Wednesday, 11 th December 1963. 7.53 p.m. ""Help me. You've got to help me."" The woman's voice quavered on the edge of tears. The duty constable who had picked up the phone heard a hiccuping gulp, as if the caller was struggling to speak."
19:53.author: Val McDermid

19:54.quote: The body was found at six minutes to eight. Doctor Young arrived some thirty minutes later. Just let me get that clear - I've a filthy memory.
19:54.author: Ngaio Marsh

19:55.quote: Flora drew her coat round her, and looked up into the darkening vault of the sky. Then she glanced at her watch. It was five to eight.
19:55.author: Stella Gibbons

19:56.quote: I remember the cigarette in his hard face, against the now limitless storm cloud. Bernardo cried to him unexpectedly: 'What time is it, Ireno?' Without consulting the sky, without stopping, he replied: 'It's four minutes to eight, young Bernardo Juan Franciso.' His voice was shrill, mocking.
19:56.author: Jorge Luis Borges

19:57.quote: "At three minutes till eight, Laszlo and His Yankee Hussars set up onstage. While the band played their Sousa medley, Carter thoroughly checked his kit, stuffing his pockets with scarves, examining the seals on decks of cards. He glanced toward his levitation device. ""Good luck, Carter."" The voice was quiet."
19:57.author: Glen David Gold

19:58.quote: Robert Langdon stole an anxious glance at his wristwatch: 7.58pm. The smiling face of Mickey Mouse did little to cheer him up.
19:58.author: Dan Brown

19:59.quote: "Kuniang made her appearance in my study just before eight o' clock, arrayed in what had once ben a ""party frock""."
19:59.author: Daniel Vare

19:59.quote: Quickly, quickly. A minute to eight. My hot water bottle was ready, and I filled a glass with water from the tap. Time was of the essence.
19:59.author: Diane Setterfield

20:00.quote: 'TIS eight o'clock,--a clear March night, The moon is up,--the sky is blue, The owlet, in the moonlight air, Shouts from nobody knows where; He lengthens out his lonely shout, Halloo! halloo! a long halloo!
20:00.author: William Wordsworth

20:00.quote: """I trace the words, I'll arrive to collect you for drinks at eight on Saturday."""
20:00.author: Chuck Palahniuk

20:00.book: The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-time
20:00.author: Mark Haddon

20:00.quote: Arthur thought he could even bear to listen to the album of bagpipe music he had won. It was eight o'clock and he decided he would make himself, force himself, to listen to the whole record before he phoned her.
20:00.book: So Long, and Thanks for All the Fish
20:00.author: Douglas Adams

20:00.quote: At eight o'clock that evening, a Saturday, Pamela Chamcha stood with Jumpy Joshi - who had refused to let her go unaccompanied - next to the Photo-Me machine in a corner of the main concourse of Euston station, feeling ridiculously conspiratorial.
20:00.author: Salman Rushdie

20:00.quote: Freud had me knock on Jung's door, to no avail. They waited until eight, then set off for Brill's without him.
20:00.author: Jed Rubenfeld

20:00.quote: I have been drunk just twice in my life, and the second time was that afternoon; so everything that happened has a dim, hazy cast over it. although until after eight o'clock the apartment was full of cheerful sun.
20:00.author: F. Scott Fitzgerald

20:00.quote: It's the twenty-third of June nineteen seventy-five, and it is eight o'clock in the evening, seated at his jigsaw puzzle, Bartlebooth has just died.
20:00.author: Georges Perec

20:00.quote: She looked at her watch- it was eight o'clock
20:00.author: F. Scott Fitzgerald

20:00.quote: That day he forgot to go to dinner; he noticed the fact at eight in the evening, and as it was too late to go to the Rue St Jaques, he ate a lump of bread.
20:00.author: Victor Hugo

20:00.quote: The clock struck eight. Had it been ten, Elinor would have been convinced that at that moment she heard a carriage driving up to the house; and so strong was the persuasion that she did, in spite of the almost impossibility of their being already come, that she moved into the adjoining dressing-closet and opened a window-shutter, to be satisfied of the truth. She instantly saw that her ears had not deceived her.
20:00.author: Jane Austen

20:01.quote: It was only a little after eight o'clock, so all the shows were about silliness or murder.
20:01.author: Kurt Vonnegut

20:02.quote: """Yes, I must go to the railway station, and if he's not there, then go there and catch him."" Anna looked at the railway timetable in the newspapers. An evening train went at two minutes past eight. ""Yes, I shall be in time."""
20:02.author: Leo Tolstoy

20:03.quote: He taught me that if I had to meet someone for an appointment, I must refuse to follow the 'stupid human habit' of arbitrarily choosing a time based on fifteen-minute intervals. 'Never meet people at 7:45 or 6:30, Jasper, but pick times like 7:12 and 8:03!'
20:03.author: Steve Toltz

20:04.quote: The earth seems to cast its darkness upward into the air. The farm country is somber at night. He is grateful when the lights of Lankaster merge with his dim beams. He stops at a diner who's clock says 8.04.
20:04.author: John Updike

20:05.quote: December 23rd At 8.05 pm Prof. Preobrazhensky commenced the first operation of its kind to be performed in Europe: removal under anaesthesia of a dog's testicles and their replacement by implanted human testes, with appendages and seminal ducts, taken from a 28-year-old human male
20:05.author: Mikhail Bulgakov

20:05.quote: Ransom took out his watch, which he had adapted, on purpose, several hours before, to Boston time, and saw that the minutes had sped with increasing velocity during this interview, and that it now marked five minutes past eight.
20:05.author: Henry James

20:06.quote: I have been drunk just twice in my life, and the second time was that afternoon; so everything that happened has a dim, hazy cast over it, although until after eight oâclock the apartment was full of cheerful sun.
20:06.author: F. Scott Fitzgerald

20:07.quote: And I could hear that there were fewer people in the little station when the train wasn't there, so I opened my eyes and I looked at my watch and it said 8:07 pm and I had been sitting on the bench for approximately 5 hours but it hadn't seemed like approximately 5 hours, except that my bottom hurt and I was hungry and thirsty.
20:07.book: The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time
20:07.author: Mark Haddon

20:07.quote: Bennie pulled the transcripts for that night. The first call had come in at 8:07, with a positive ID.
20:07.author: Lisa Scottoline

20:10.quote: At 2010h. on 1 April Y.D.A.U., the medical attache is still watching the unlabelled entertainment cartridge.
20:10.author: David Foster Wallace

20:14.quote: When a call came through to Dilworthâs home number at fourteen minutes past eight oâclock, Olbier and Jones reacted with far more excitement than the situation warranted because they were desperate for action.
20:14.author: Dean Koontz

20:15.quote: 8:15 p.m. Cannot locate operating instructions (for video)
20:15.author: Helen Fielding

20:15.book: The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-time
20:15.author: Mark Haddon

20:15.quote: "Natsha: I was looking to see if there wasn't a fire. It's Shrovetide, and the servant is simply beside herself; I must look out that something doesn't happen. When I came through the dining-room yesterday midnight, there was a candle burning. I couldn't get her to tell me who had lighted it. [Puts down her candle] What's the time? Andrey: [Looks at his watch] A quarter past eight. Natasha: And Olga and Irina aren't in yet. The poor things are still at work. Olga at the teachers' council, Irina at the telegraph office...[sighs] I said to your sister this morning, ""Irina, darling, you must take care of yourself."" But she pays no attention. Did you say it was a quarter past eight?"
20:15.author: Anton Chekhov

20:16.quote: He kissed her hand and after a while went to get two more drinks. When he got back, it was sixteen minutes past eight, and Lois was humming softly along with the jukebox
20:16.author: Jonathan Coe

20:17.quote: 20.17 A red warning light failed to go on in the Drive Room, beginning a chain of events which would lead, in a further twenty-three minutes, to the total annihilation of the entire crew of Red Dwarf.
20:17.author: Grant Naylor

20:18.quote: 2018 hrs Katya has arrived at the Odessa Hotel. Barley and Katya are talking in the canteen. Wicklow and one irregular observing. More.
20:18.author: John le Carre

20:20.book: The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-time
20:20.author: Mark Haddon

20:20.quote: At 20.20 all ships had completed oiling. Hove to, they had had the utmost difficulty in keeping position in that great wind; but they were infinitely safer than in the open sea
20:20.author: Alistair MacLean

20:20.quote: Knowing that the dinner was only for us six, we never dreamed it would be a full dress affair. I had no appetite. It was quite twenty minutes past eight before we sat down to dinner.
20:20.author: George and Weedon Grossmith

20:21.quote: "At 8.21, after a knock at the door, a constable said a military police vehicle had just driven into the courtyard, the driver asking for ""Mr."" Murray."
20:21.author: Len Deighton

20:23.quote: 20.23. In a few minutes she would go down.She could have borrowed some mascara from her daughter Sally, but it was too late. She could have rung her mother in Northam, but it was too late. Seven minutes of solitude she had, and then she would descend.
20:23.author: Margaret Drabble

20:24.quote: Peach checked his watch. 8.24. If he wasn't in a taxi in twenty minutes he'd be done for.
20:24.author: Rupert Thomson

20:25.quote: She sat down in her usual seat and smiled at her husband as he sank into his own chair opposite her. She was saved. It was only five and twenty past eight.
20:25.author: Agatha Christie

20:27.quote: At seven-and-twenty minutes past eight Mrs Lofthouse was seated at Aurora's piano, in the first agonies of a prelude in six flats; a prelude which demanded such extraordinary uses of the left hand across the right, and the right over the left, and such exercise of the thumbs in all positions
20:27.author: Mary Elizabeth Braddon

20:29.quote: """Twenty-nine and a half minutes past eight, sir."" And then, from habit, he glanced at the clock in the tower, and made further oration. ""By George! that clock's half an hour fast! First time in ten years I've known it to be off. This watch of mine never varies a--"" But the citizen was talking to vacancy. He turned and saw his hearer, a fast receding black shadow, flying in the direction of a house with three lighted upper windows."
20:29.timeAlt: Twenty-nine and a half minutes past eight
20:29.author: O. Henry

20:30.quote: "Alix took up a piece of needlework and began to stitch. Gerald read a few pages of his book. Then he glanced up at the clock and tossed the book away. ""Half-past eight. Time to go down to the cellar and start work."""
20:30.author: Agatha Christie

20:30.quote: The bicycles go by in twos and threes - there's a dance on in Billy Brennan's barn tonight, and there's the half-talk code of mysteries and the wink-and-elbow language of delight. Half-past eight and there is not a spot upon a mile of road, no shadow thrown that might turn out a man or woman,
20:30.author: Patrick Kavanagh

20:32.quote: "At the station he captured Miss Lantry out of the gadding mob at eight thirty-two. ""We mustn't keep mamma and the others waiting,"" said she. ""To Wallack's Theatre as fast as you can drive!"""
20:32.author: O. Henry

20:33.quote: 20.33 Navigation officer Henri DuBois knocked his black cona coffee with four sugars over his computer console keyboard. As he mopped up the coffee, he noticed three red warning blips on his monitor screen, which he wrongly assumed were the result of his spillage.
20:33.author: Grant Naylor

20:35.quote: Left Munich at 8.35 p.m. on 1st May, arriving at Vienna early the next morning
20:35.author: Bram Stoker

20:35.quote: She paused reflectively. He was keenly interested now, not a doubt of it. The murderer is bound to have an interest in murder. She had gambled on that, and succeeded. She stole a glance at the clock. It was five and twenty to nine.
20:35.author: Agatha Christie

20:36.quote: 20.36 Rimmer stood in the main wash-room on the stasis deck and combed his hair.
20:36.author: Grant Naylor

20:40.quote: It was when I stood before her, avoiding her eyes, that I took note of the surrounding objects in detail, and saw that her watch had stopped at twenty minutes to nine, and that a clock in the room had stopped at twenty minutes to nine.
20:40.author: Charles Dickens

20:40.quote: The letter had been brought in at twenty minutes to nine.
20:40.author: Agatha Christie

20:42.quote: The hand at this moment pointed to 8.42. The players took up their cards, but their eyes were constantly on the clock. One may safely say that, however secure they might feel, never had minutes seemed so long to them.
20:42.book: Around the World in Eighty Days
20:42.author: Jules Verne

20:43.quote: '8.43,' said Thomas Flanagan, as he cut the cards placed before him by Gauthier Ralph. There was a moment's pause, during which the spacious room was perfectly silent.
20:43.book: Around the world in eighty days
20:43.author: Jules Verne

20:44.quote: "The clock's pendulum beat every second with mathematical regularity, and each player could count every sixtieth of a minute as it struck his ear.""8.44!"" said John Sullivan, in a voice that betrayed his emotion.Only one minute more and the wager would be won."
20:44.book: Around the World in Eighty Days
20:44.author: Jules Verne

20:45.quote: 'It's not impossible,' Phileas said quietly.'I bet you 20,000 pounds I could do it. If I leave this evening on the 8.45 train to Dover, I can be back here at the Reform Club by 8.45 on Saturday 21 December. I'll get my passport stamped at every place i stop to prove I've been around the world.'
20:45.book: Around the World in Eighty Days
20:45.author: Jules Verne

20:45.quote: Beaver arrived at quarter to nine in a state of high self-approval; he had refused two invitations for dinner while dressing that evening; he had cashed a cheque for ten pounds at his club; he had booked a Divan table at Espinosa's.
20:45.author: Evelyn Waugh

20:46.quote: At the tone, the time will be eight forty six, exactly. One cubic mile of seawater contains about 50 pounds of gold.
20:46.author: Tom Lichtenberg

20:49.quote: 8.49. I took the phone, cleared my throat, and dialled the keep, the packs stronghold on the outskirts of Atlanta. Just keep it professional. Less pathetic that way.
20:49.author: Ilona Andrews

20:50.quote: "8.50pm. Ah Diagram ""Buttons for IMC functions"". But what are IMC functions?"
20:50.author: Helen Fielding

20:50.quote: all the clocks in London were striking ten minutes before nine.
20:50.book: Around the world in eighty days
20:50.author: Jules Verne

20:50.quote: He glanced at the bracket-clock on the mantelpiece, but as this had stopped, drew out his watch. 'It is already too late,' he said. 'It wants only ten minutes to nine.' 'Good God!' she exclaimed, turning quite pale. 'What am I to do?'
20:50.author: Georgette Heyer

20:50.quote: He was, yes, always home from work by 2050 on Thursdays.
20:50.author: David Foster Wallace

20:50.quote: What did it mean by beginning to tick so loudly all of a sudden? Its face indicated ten minutes to nine. Mrs Verloc cared nothing for time, and the ticking went on.
20:50.author: Joseph Conrad

20:53.quote: Only eight fifty-three. The partners' decision meeting starts in seven minutes. I'm not sure I can bear this.
20:53.author: Sophie Kinsella

20:55.quote: And the past. The clock on the dash said 8:55pm. And the last pink shard of the sun was reaching up into the night sky, desperately trying to hold on for just one more minute.
20:55.author: Chris Cole

20:56.quote: "âNo. 7 berthâa second-class. The gentleman has not yet come, and it is four minutes to nine."""
20:56.author: Agatha Christie

20:57.quote: """Wait,"" he said solemnly, ""till the clock strikes. I have wealth and power and knowledge above most men, but when the clock strikes I am afraid. Stay by me until then. This woman shall be yours. You have the word of the hereditary Prince of Valleluna. On the day of your marriage I will give you $100,000 and a palace on the Hudson. But there must be no clocks in that palace--they measure our follies and limit our pleasures. Do you agree to that?"" ""Of course,"" said the young man, cheerfully, ""they're a nuisance, anyway--always ticking and striking and getting you late for dinner."" He glanced again at the clock in the tower. The hands stood at three minutes to nine."
20:57.author: O. Henry

20:58.quote: """What time is it?"" she asked, quiet, definite, hopeless. ""Two minutes to nine,"" he replied, telling the truth with a struggle."
20:58.author: D H Lawrence

21:00.quote: 9.00 p.m. Watch television or a video
21:00.book: The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-time
21:00.author: Mark Haddon

21:00.quote: At 2100 at night it's cold out.
21:00.author: David Foster Wallace

21:00.quote: It was nine o'clock at night upon the second of Augustâthe most terrible August in the history of the world. One might have thought already that God's curse hung heavy over a degenerate world, for there was an awesome hush and a feeling of vague expectancy in the sultry and stagnant air
21:00.book: His Last Bow An Epilogue of Sherlock Holmes
21:00.author: Arthur Conan Doyle

21:00.quote: On the evening before K.'s thirty-first birthday - it was about nine o'clock, when there is a lull in the streets - two gentlemen came to his apartment.
21:00.author: Franz Kafka

21:00.quote: On the stroke of nine oâclock Mr. and Mrs. De Voted took their places on either side of the drawing-room fire, in attitudes of gracefully combined hospitality and unconcern, Vivian De Voted wearing a black beard and black velvet jacket buttoned over his Bohemian bosom, his lady in a flowing purple gown embroidered in divers appropriate places with pomegranates and their leaves.
21:00.author: Katherine Mansfield

21:00.quote: Shortly after nine o'clock that evening, Weyrother drove with his plans to Kutuzov's quarters where the council of war was to be held. All the commanders of columns were summoned to the commander in chief's and with the exception of Prince Bagration, who declined to come, were all there at the appointed time.
21:00.author: Leo Tolstoy

21:00.quote: Standing in the chrome-and-tile desolation of the Polar-Shtern Kafeteria at nine o'clock on a Friday night, in a snowstorm, he's the loneliest Jew in the Sitka District.
21:00.author: Michael Chabon

21:00.quote: That night at nine the President addressed the nation.
21:00.author: Bernstein & Woodward

21:00.quote: Then he put on a grey jacket and left the flat to make his way to Praca da Alegria. It was already nine o'clock, Pereira maintains.
21:00.author: Antonio Tabucchi

21:00.quote: This time, the putting on of her best hat at nine o'clock at night with the idea of sallying forth from the castle, down the long drive and then northwards along the acacia avenue, had been enough to send her to her own doorway as though she suspected someone might be there, someone who was listening to her thoughts.
21:00.author: Mervyn Peake

21:01.quote: On the evening before K.'s thirty-first birthday - it was about nine o'clock, when there is a lull in the streets - two gentlemen came to his apartment.
21:01.author: Franz Kafka

21:02.quote: The good Brants did not allow the boys to play out after nine in summer evenings; they were sent to bed at that hour; Eddie honorably remained, but Georgie usually slipped out of the window toward ten, and enjoyed himself until midnight.
21:02.book: Edward Mills and George Benton: A Tale
21:02.author: Mark Twain

21:03.quote: Billy Weaver had travelled down from London on the slow afternoon train, with a change at Swindon on the way, and by the time he got to Bath it was about nine oâclock in the evening and the moon was coming up out of a clear starry sky over the houses opposite the station entrance. But the air was deadly cold and the wind was like a flat blade of ice on his cheeks.
21:03.author: Roald Dahl

21:04.quote: At 9.04pm trilobites swim onto the scene, followed more or less immediately by the shapely creatures of the Burgess Shale.
21:04.book: A Short History of Nearly Everything
21:04.author: Bill Bryson

21:05.quote: "Nine-five. A voice spoke from the study ceiling: ""Mrs. McClellan, which poem would you like this evening?"". The house was silent. The voice said at last, ""Since you express no preference, I shall select a poem at random."""
21:05.author: Ray Bradbury

21:09.quote: 9.09. Too late to turn around and go back. Too late, too dangerous.
21:09.author: Rupert Thomson

21:11.quote: Every few seconds the house changed character, at one time menacing and sinister, and again the innocent abode of law-abiding citizens about to be attacked by my private army. The luminous watch said 9.11.
21:11.author: Len Deighton

21:12.quote: The crime was reported to us (with almost indecent alacrity, Rog) at 21.12, by Susan Trott - of Black Grouse Cottage - who had been, I quote: 'out looking for hedgehogs when I was horrified to notice the postbox door had fallen off and was just lying there, on the ground'.
21:12.author: Nicola Barker

21:15.quote: What are we going to do? Should we try to walk to Clapham High Street? But it's bloody miles away. I glance at my watch and am shocked to see that it's nine-fifteen. We've spent over an hour faffing about and we haven't even had a drink. And it's all my fault. I can't even organize one simple evening without its going catastrophically wrong.
21:15.author: Sophie Kinsella

21:17.quote: 21:17, Sunday Evening, Angbyplan. A man is observed outside the hair salon. He presses his face and hands against the glass, and appears extremely intoxicated.
21:17.author: John Ajvide Lindqvist

21:18.quote: The same thing would hold true if there were someone in her apartment. In that case he would just say that he had been passing by, recognized her charming house, and thought to drop in. It was eighteen minutes after nine when Mr. Martin turned into Twelfth Street.
21:18.author: James Thurber

21:20.quote: 9.20 p.m. Have juice and a snack
21:20.book: The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-time
21:20.author: Mark Haddon

21:22.quote: Fifteen minutes later (21.22 hrs), Miss Squire arrives in Skipton where she is booked into a local B&B. This B&B is located directly across the road from Mhairi Callaghan's Feathercuts.
21:22.author: Nicola Barker

21:23.quote: My father met me at the station, the dog jumped up to meet me, missed, and nearly fell in front of the 9.23pm Birmingham express.
21:23.book: The Secret Diary of Adrian Mole Aged 13 3/4
21:23.author: Sue Townsend

21:25.quote: 9:25 p.m. Aargh. Suddenly main menu is on TV saying Press 6. Realize was using telly remote control by mistake. Now News has come on
21:25.author: Helen Fielding

21:28.quote: From that moment on--9:28 in the evening, June 18, 1941--everything was different.
21:28.author: Jonathan Safran Foer

21:30.book: The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-time
21:30.author: Mark Haddon

21:30.quote: Forty-eight years old, profoundly asleep at nine thirty on a Friday night - this is modern professional life.
21:30.author: Ian McEwan

21:30.quote: It's 9:30 p.m. already. I've gotta head uptown for my appointment with Pavel. Pavel is my shrink. He sees patients at night. He's a Czech Jew, a survivor of Terezin and Auswitz. I see him once a week.
21:30.author: Art Spiegelman

21:30.quote: The light in Mr. Green's kitchen snapped off at nine-thirty, followed by the light in his bedroom at his usual ten o'clock. His house was the first on the street to go dark.
21:30.author: Suzanne Berne

21:31.quote: "I took some juice out of the refrigerator and sat down at the kitchen table with it. On the table was a note from my girlfriend: ""Gone out to eat. Back by 9:30."" The digital clock on the table read 9:30. I watched it flip over to 9:31, then to 9:32."
21:31.author: Haruki Murakami

21:32.quote: "I took some juice out of the refrigerator and sat down at the kitchen table with it. On the table was a note from my girlfriend: ""Gone out to eat. Back by 9:30."" The digital clock on the table read 9:30. I watched it flip over to 9:31, then to 9:32."
21:32.author: Haruki Murakami

21:34.quote: Thanks; expect me 9.34 p.m. 26th'; which produced, three hours later, a reply: 'Delighted; please bring a No. 3 Rippingille stove' - a perplexing and ominous direction, which somehow chilled me in spite of its subject matter.
21:34.author: Erskine Childers

21:35.quote: The Sergeant jotted it down on a piece of paper. 'That checks up with his own story: 9.35 p.m. Budd leaves; the North dame arrives.'
21:35.author: Georgette Heyer

21:36.quote: My backpack was already packed, and I'd already gotten the other supplies together, like the altimeter and the granola bars and the Swiss army knife I'd dug up in Central Park, so there was nothing else to do. Mom tucked me in at 9:36.
21:36.author: Jonathan Safran Foer

21:38.quote: At nine thirty-eight the waiter came back and offered us a second helping of cheese,salami and sardines, and Mr Yoshogi who had been converting sterling into yen looked extremely puzzled and said he had no idea that British Honduras had so large an export trade
21:38.author: David Footman

21:42.quote: Langdon looked at his Mickey Mouse watch. 9:42 P.M.
21:42.author: Dan Brown

21:45.quote: But for some unfathomable reason-birth, death, the end of the universe and all things available to man-Cody Menhoff's was closed at 9:45 PM on a Thursday...
21:45.author: T. C. Boyle

21:47.quote: For Hunter, who was trained to note times exactly, the final emergency started at thirteen minutes to ten.
21:47.author: CJ Driver

21:50.quote: I passed out on to the road and saw by the lighted dial of a clock that it was ten minutes to ten. In front of me was a large building which displayed the magical name.
21:50.author: James Joyce

21:57.quote: Second to last, the inset clock blinks from 21:57 to 21:58. Napier's eyes sink, newborn sunshine slants through ancient oaks and on a lost river. Look, Joe, herons
21:57.author: David Mitchell

21:57.quote: "The waiting man pulled out a handsome watch, the lids of it set with small diamonds. ""Three minutes to ten,"" he announced."
21:57.author: O. Henry

21:58.quote: Second to last, the inset clock blinks from 21:57 to 21:58. Napier's eyes sink, newborn sunshine slants through ancient oaks and on a lost river. Look, Joe, herons
21:58.author: David Mitchell

21:59.quote: The first night, as soon as the corporal had conducted my uncle Toby upstairs, which was about 10 - Mrs. Wadman threw herself into her arm chair
21:59.book: The Life and Opinions of Tristram Shandy, Gentleman
21:59.author: Laurence Sterne

22:00.quote: By ten, Quoyle was drunk. The crowd was enormous, crushed together so densely that Nutbeem could not force his way down the hall or to the door and urinated on the remaining potato chips in the blue barrel, setting a popular example.
22:00.author: E. Annie Proulx

22:00.quote: Her body asserted itself with a restless movement of the knee, and she stood up. 'Ten o'clock,' she remarked, apparently finding the time on the ceiling. 'Time for this good girl to go to bed.'
22:00.author: F. Scott Fitzgerald

22:00.quote: "I could not doubt that this was the BLACK SPOT; and taking it up, I found written on the other side, in a very good, clear hand, this short message: ""You have till ten tonight."""
22:00.author: Robert Louis Stevenson

22:00.quote: I went back into the library, limp and exhausted. In a few minutes the telephone began ringing again. I did not do anything. I let it ring. I went and sat down at Maxim's feet. It went on ringing. I did not move. Presently it stopped, as though cut suddenly in exasperation. The clock on the mantelpiece struck ten o'clock. Maxim put his arms round me and lifted me against him. We began to kiss one another, feverishly, desperately, like guilty lovers who have not kissed before.
22:00.author: Daphne du Maurier

22:00.quote: "No one wanted to go to bed when at ten o'clock Mrs. March put by the last finished job, and said, ""Come girls."" Beth went to the piano and played the father's favorite hymn."
22:00.author: Louisa May Alcott

22:00.quote: The grandfather clock in the State Room strikes ten times.
22:00.book: The Thousand Autumns of Jacob de Zoet
22:00.author: David Mitchell

22:00.quote: The light in Mr. Green's kitchen snapped off at nine-thirty, followed by the light in his bedroom at his usual ten o'clock. His house was the first on the street to go dark.
22:00.author: Suzanne Berne

22:00.quote: They were alone then, and theoretically free to do whatever they wanted, but they went on eating the dinner they had no appetite for. Florence set down her knife and reached for Edward's hand and squeezed. From downstairs they heard the wireless, the chimes of Big Ben at the start of the ten o'clock news.
22:00.author: Ian McEwan

22:00.quote: We let our upstairs room to a certain Mr. Goudsmit, a divorced man in his thirties, who appeared to have nothing to do on this particular evening; we simply could not get rid of him without being rude; he hung about until ten o'clock.
22:00.book: Anne Frank: The Diary of a Young Girl
22:00.author: Anne Frank

22:02.quote: It was now 10.02pm. He has less than two hours.
22:02.author: Dan Brown

22:05.quote: The A-B elevator was our elevator, the elevator on which the paramedics came up at 9:20 p.m., the elevator on which they took John (and me) downstairs to the ambulance at 10:05 p.m.
22:05.author: Joan Didion

22:06.quote: Of course, they had good reason to be fussy on such a night. And then it was long after ten o'clock and yet there was no sign of Gabriel and his wife. Besides they were dreadfully afraid that Freddy Malins might turn up screwed.
22:06.author: James Joyce

22:08.quote: """My watch is always a little fast,"" I said. ""What time do you make it now?"" ""Ten eight."" ""Ten eighteen by mine. You see."""
22:08.author: Graham Greene

22:10.quote: That was the past, and now I had just died on the narrow couch of a Paris lodging house, and my wife was crouching on the floor, crying bitterly. The white light before my left eye was growing dim, but I remembered the room perfectly. On the left there was a chest of drawers, on the right a mantelpiece surmounted by a damaged clock without a pendulum, the hands of which marked ten minutes past ten. The window overlooked the Rue Dauphine, a long, dark street. All Paris seemed to pass below, and the noise was so great that the window shook.
22:10.author: Emile Zola

22:10.quote: 10.10pm. When you turn your recorder on you must adjust clock and the calendar.......Press red and nothing happens. Press numbers and nothing happens. Wish stupid video had never been invented.
22:10.author: Helen Fielding

22:11.quote: Therefore a sergeant called Trifonov had been on post all day or all week and then he had left at eleven minutes past ten in the evening.
22:11.author: Lee Child

22:12.quote: The Chinese women scuttled at an amazing rate, given their size and the bags' size. It was c. 2212:30-40h., smack in the middle of the former Interval of Issues Resolution.
22:12.author: David Foster Wallace

22:14.quote: The shopping bags looked heavy and impressive, their weight making the Chinese women lean in slightly towards each other. Call it 2214:10h.
22:14.author: David Foster Wallace

22:15.quote: 10:15 p.m. Aargh Newsnight on in 15 minutes
22:15.author: Helen Fielding

22:17.quote: 10:17 p. m. Casette will not go in
22:17.author: Helen Fielding

22:18.quote: """My watch is always a little fast,"" I said. ""What time do you make it now?"" ""Ten eight."" ""Ten eighteen by mine. You see."""
22:18.author: Graham Greene

22:18.quote: 10:18pm. Ah. Thelma and Louise is in there
22:18.author: Helen Fielding

22:20.quote: "At 10:20 she returned with a shopping bag from the supermarket. In the bag were three scrub brushes, one box of paperclips and a well-chilled six-pack of canned beer. So I had another beer. ""It was about sheep,"" I said. ""Didn't I tell you?"" she said."
22:20.author: Haruki Murakami

22:21.quote: 10:21pm. Frenziedly press all buttons. Cassette comes out and goes back in again
22:21.author: Helen Fielding

22:21.quote: 10:21pm. Thelma and Louise will not come out
22:21.author: Helen Fielding

22:21.quote: On a Saturday c. 2221h., Lenz found a miniature bird that had fallen out of some nest and was sitting bald and pencil-necked on the lawn of Unit #3 flapping ineffectually, and went in with Green and ducked Green and went back outside to # 3's lawn and put the thing in a pocket and went in and put it down the garbage disposal in the kitchen sink of the kitchen, but still felt largely impotent and unresolved.
22:21.author: David Foster Wallace

22:21.quote: On a Saturday c. 2221h., Lenz found a miniature bird that had fallen out of some nest and was sitting bald and pencil-necked on the lawn of Unit #3 flapping ineffectually...
22:21.author: David Foster Wallace

22:24.quote: Thanks to ten minutes or so of balmy weather, by 10:24 the Earth is covered in the great carboniferous forests whose residues give us all our coal, and the first winged insects are evident.
22:24.book: A Short History of Nearly Everything
22:24.author: Bill Bryson

22:25.quote: "10:25pm. Got new cassette in now. Right. Turn to ""Recording.................. Aargh Newsnight is starting"
22:25.author: Helen Fielding

22:26.quote: As always, consciousness returned to me progressively from the edges of my field of vision. The first things to claim recognition were the bathroom door emerging from the far right and a lamp from the far left, from which my awareness gradually drifted inward like ice flowing together toward the middle of a lake. In the exact center of my visual field was the alarm clock, hands pointing to ten-twenty-six.
22:26.book: Hard Boiled Wonderland and the End of the World
22:26.author: Haruki Murakami

22:27.quote: Mr Harcourt woke up with mysterious suddenness at twenty-seven minutes past 10, and, by a curious coincidence, it was at that very instant that the butler came in with two footmen laden with trays of whisky, brandy, syphons, glasses and biscuits.
22:27.author: AG Macdonell

22:30.quote: She looked at the clock; it was ten thirty. If she could get there quickly on the subway, then she could be at his house in less than an hour, maybe a bit longer if the late trains did not come so often.
22:30.author: Colm Toibin

22:30.quote: The time was ten-thirty but it could have been three in the morning, because along its borders, West Berlin goes to bed with the dark
22:30.author: John Le Carre

22:31.quote: 10.31pm. Ok OK. Calm. Penny Husbands-Bosworth, so asbestos leukaemia item is not on yet.
22:31.author: Helen Fielding

22:31.quote: And, later on, at 10.31 pm, I went out onto the balcony to find out whether I could see any stars, but there weren't any because of all the clouds and what is called Light Pollution which is light from streetlights and car headlights and floodlights and lights in buildings reflecting off tiny particles in the atmosphere and getting in the way of light from the stars. So I went back inside.
22:31.book: The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-time
22:31.author: Mark Haddon

22:33.quote: 10:33 p.m. Yessss, yessss. RECORDING CURRENT PROGRAMME. Have done it. Aargh. All going mad. Cassette has started rewinding and now stopped and ejected. Why? Shit. Shit. Realize in excitement have sat on remote control.
22:33.author: Helen Fielding

22:33.quote: 10:33pm. Yessss, yessss. RECORDING CURRENT PROGRAMME. Have done it. Aargh. All going mad. Cassette has started rewinding and now stopped and ejected. Why? Shit. Shit. Realize in excitement have sat on remote control.
22:33.author: Helen Fielding

22:35.quote: 10:35 p.m. Frantic now. Have rung Sahzzer, Rebecca, Simon, Magda. Nobody knows how to programme their videos. Only person I know who knows how to do it is Daniel.
22:35.author: Helen Fielding

22:40.quote: The station clock told him the time: twenty to eleven. He went to the booking office and asked the clerk in a polite tone when was the next train to Paris. 'In twelve minutes.'
22:40.book: The Man Who Watched the Trains Go By
22:40.author: Georges Simenon

22:41.quote: "He climbed into the front seat and started the car. It started with a merry powerful hum, ready to go. ""There, the bastards"", said Julian, and smashed the clock with the bottom of the bottle, to give them an approximate time. It was 10:41"
22:41.author: John O'Hara

22:44.quote: "Alec pricked up his ears. ""When was that?"" ""Oh, yesterday evening."" ""What time?"" ""About a quarter to eleven. I was playing bridge."""
22:44.author: Carola Dunn

22:45.quote: 10.45pm. Oh God Daniel fell about laughing when I said I could not programme video. Said he would do it for me. Still at least I have done best for Mum. It is exciting and historic when one's friends are on TV.
22:45.author: Helen Fielding

22:45.quote: So the Lackadaisical Broadcasting Co. bids you farewell with the message that if you aren't grateful to be living in a world where so many things to be grateful for are yours as a matter of course. Why it is now five seconds until fifteen minutes before eleven o'clock and you are just an old Trojan Horse.
22:45.author: Ogden Nash

22:46.quote: The 'night train' tallied to perfection, for high tide in the creek would be, as Davies estimated, between 10.30 and 11.00 p.m.on the night of the 25th; and the time-table showed that the only night train arriving at Norden was one from the south at 10.46 p.m.
22:46.author: Erskine Childers

22:48.quote: """Oh! I don't know about that,"" said Mr. Satterthwaite, warming to his subject. ""I was down there for a bit last summer. I found it quite convenient for town. Of course the trains only go every hour. 48 minutes past the hour from Waterloo-up to 10.48."""
22:48.author: Agatha Christie

22:49.quote: It's well after 2245h. The dog's leash slides hissing to the end of the Day-Glo line and stops the dog a couple of paces from the inside of the gate, where Lenz is standing, inclined in the slight forward way of somebody who's talking baby-talk to a dog.
22:49.author: David Foster Wallace

22:50.quote: 10.50 P. M. This diary-keeping of mine is, I fancy, the outcome of that scientific habit of mind about which I wrote this morning. I like to register impressions while they are fresh.
22:50.author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle

22:50.quote: "Saturday night. And I said, 'It's a hundred this year, ain't anybody noticed?'""Jack said, 'What's a hundred?' I said, 'Pub is. Coach is. Look at the clock.' Jack said, âIt's ten to elevenâ."
22:50.author: Graham Swift

22:50.quote: So think yourself lucky while you're awake and remember a happy crew. Think of Hamburg on the Magic Night. 22.50 and they went out neatly, just as they should - you couldn't fault Parks, he was always on his route.
22:50.author: A. L. Kennedy

22:55.quote: """It is eleven o'clock! Eleven o'clock, all but five minutes!"" ""But which eleven o'clock?"" ""The eleven o'clock that is to decide life or death!...He told me so just before he went....He is terrible....He is quite mad: he tore off his mask and his yellow eyes shot flames!..."""
22:55.timeAlt: Eleven o'clock, all but five minutes!
22:55.author: Gaston Leroux

22:58.quote: Then it grew dark; she would have had them to bed, but they begged sadly to be allowed to stay up; and, just about eleven oâclock, the door-latch was raised quietly, and in stepped the master.
22:58.author: Emily BrontÃ«

22:59.quote: They parked the car outside Lowther's at precisely one minute to eleven. People were leaving, not all of them happy at having their evening curtailed. But the grumbling was muted, and even then it only started once they were safely on the street.
22:59.author: Ian Rankin

23:00.quote: 'He will be here at eleven exactly, sir.' At the bar, naked couples had begun dancing.
23:00.author: John le Carre

23:00.quote: At eleven o'clock that night, having secured a bed at one of the hotels and telegraphed his address to his father immediately on his arrival, he walked out into the streets of Sandbourne.
23:00.author: Thomas Hardy

23:00.quote: At eleven o'clock, I rang the bell for Betteredge, and told Mr. Blake that he might at last prepare himself for bed.
23:00.author: Wilkie Collins

23:00.quote: "He says, ""They've killed Jan. Clear out."" ""The suitcase?"" I ask. ""Take it away again. We want nothing to do with it now. Catch the eleven o'clock express."" ""But it doesn't stop here...."" ""It will. Go to track six. Opposite the freight station. You have three minutes."" ""But..."" ""Move, or I'll have to arrest you."""
23:00.book: If on a winter's night a traveller
23:00.author: Italo Calvino

23:00.quote: The clock struck eleven. I looked at Adele, whose head leant against my shoulder; her eyes were waxing heavy, so I took her up in my arms and carried her off to bed. It was near one before the gentlemen and ladies sought their chambers.
23:00.author: Charlotte BrontÃ«

23:00.quote: The clock struck eleven. I looked at Adele, whose head leant against my shoulder; her eyes were waxing heavy, so I took her up in my arms and carried her off to bed. It was near one before the gentlemen and ladies sought their chambers.
23:00.author: Charlotte BrontÃ«

23:00.quote: The train arrived in New York at eleven that night.
23:00.author: William Gaddis

23:00.quote: They didn't even sit down to eat until 2300h.
23:00.author: David Foster Wallace

23:00.quote: When they reached the top of the Astronomy Tower at eleven o'clock, they found a perfect night for stargazing, cloudless and still.
23:00.book: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix
23:00.author: JK Rowling

23:03.quote: """What makes you think it's for real?"" ""Just a hunch, really. He sounded for real. Sometimes you can just tell about people""-he smiled-""even if you're a dull old WASP."" ""I think it's a setup."" ""Why?"" ""I just do. Why would someone from the government want to help you?"" ""Good question. Guess I'll find out."" She went back into the kitchen.""What time are you meeting him?"" she called out. ""Eleven oh-three,"" he said. ""That made me think he's for real. Military and intelligence types set precise appointment times to eliminate confusion and ambiguity. Nothing ambiguous about eleven oh-three."""
23:03.author: Christopher Buckley

23:05.quote: It was 11.05, five minutes later than my habitual bedtime. I felt. I felt guilty at being still up, but the past kept pricking at me and I knew that all the events of those nineteen days in July were astir within me, like the loosening phlegm in an attack of bronchitis
23:05.author: L.P.Hartley

23:05.quote: It was five minutes past eleven when I made my last entry. I remember winding up my watch and noting the time. So I have wasted some five hours of the little span still left to us. Who would have believed it possible? But I feel very much fresher, and ready for my fate--or try to persuade myself that I am. And yet, the fitter a man is, and the higher his tide of life, the more must he shrink from death. How wise and how merciful is that provision of nature by which his earthly anchor is usually loosened by many little imperceptible tugs, until his consciousness has drifted out of its untenable earthly harbor into the great sea beyond!
23:05.author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle

23:05.quote: My watch says 11:05. But whether AM or PM I don't know.
23:05.author: Stanley Donwood

23:07.quote: "At 11.07 pm, Samuel ""Gunner"" Wilson was moving at 645 miles per hour over the Mojave Desert. Up ahead in the moonlinght, he saw the twin lead jets, their afterburners glowing angrily in the night sky."
23:07.author: Michael Crichton

23:10.quote: Another Christmas day is nearly over. It's ten past eleven. Richard declined with thanks my offer to make up a bed for him here in my study, and has driven off back to Cambridge, so I am able to make some notes on the day before going to bed myself.
23:10.author: David Lodge

23:10.quote: He had not the strength to help himself, and at ten minutes past eleven no one could have helped him, no one in the world
23:10.author: John O'Hara

23:11.quote: "Life changes fast Life changes in an instant You sit down to dinner and life as you know it ends. The Question of self-pity. Those were the first words I wrote after it happened. The computer dating on the Microsoft Word file (""Notes on change.doc"") reads ""May 20, 2004, 11:11 p.m.,"" but that would have been a case of my opening the file and reflexively pressing save when I closed it. I had made no changes to that file since I wrote the words, in January 2004, a day or two after the fact. For a long time I wrote nothing else. Life changes in the instant. The ordinary instant."
23:11.author: Joan Didion

23:12.quote: There was a confirmatory identification done by undercover officer 6475 at 23:12 hours at the corner of 147th and Amsterdam.
23:12.author: Sergio De La Pava

23:15.quote: "11.15pm. Humph. Mum just rang ""Sorry, darling. It isn't Newsnigtht, it's Breakfast News tomorrow. Could you set it for seven o'clock tomorrow morning, BBC1?"""
23:15.author: Helen Fielding

23:15.quote: On arriving home at a quarter-past eleven, we found a hansom cab, which had been waiting for me for two hours with a letter. Sarah said she did not know what to do, as we had not left the address where we had gone.
23:15.author: George and Weedon Grossmith

23:16.quote: But I couldn't get out of the house straight away because he would see me, so I would have to wait until he was asleep. The time was 11.16 pm. I tried doubling 2s again, but I couldn't get past 2(15) which was 32,768. So I groaned to make the time pass quicker and not think.
23:16.book: The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-time
23:16.author: Mark Haddon

23:18.quote: It is 11.18. A row of bungalows in a round with a clump of larch tree in the middle.
23:18.author: Jackie Kay

23:19.quote: A whistle cut sharply across his words. Peter got onto his knees to look out the window, and Miss Fuller glared at him. Polly looked down at her watch: 11:19. The train. But the stationmaster had said it was always late.
23:19.author: Connie Willis

23:20.quote: From Balboa Island, he drove south to Laguna Beach. At eleven-twenty, he parked his van across the street from the Hudston house.
23:20.author: Dean Koontz

23:20.quote: "Harvey looked at the clock, which marked twenty past eleven. ""Then I'll sleep here till three and catch the four o'clock freight. They let us men from the Fleet ride free as a rule."""
23:20.author: Rudyard Kipling

23:22.quote: At 11.22 he handed his ticket to a yawning guard and walked down a long flight of wooden steps to the car-park. A breeze lifted and dropped the leaves of a tree, and he thought of the girl with the blonde hair. His bicycle lay where he had left it.
23:22.author: Robert Thomson

23:25.quote: """OK, Estelle, I willl be at Nice Airport at 11.25 p.m. on Saturday, BA: Could you send the driver?"""
23:25.author: Justin Cartwright

23:25.quote: To test the intensity of the light whose nature and cause he could not determine, he took out his watch to see if he could make out the figures on the dial. They were plainly visible, and the hands indicated the hour of eleven o'clock and twenty-five minutes. At that moment the mysterious illumination suddenly flared to an intense, an almost blinding splendorâ¦
23:25.author: Ambrose Bierce

23:26.quote: Los Angeles. 11:26 p.m. In a dark red room- the color of the walls is close to that of raw liver- is a tall woman dressed cartoonishly in too-tight silk shorts, her breasts pulled up and pressed forward by the yellow blouse tied beneath them.
23:26.author: Neil Gaiman

23:27.quote: "He tells his old friend the train times and they settle on the 19.45 arriving at 23.27. ""I'll book us into the ultra-luxurious Francis Drake Lodge. Running water in several rooms. Have you got a mobile?"""
23:27.author: Justin Cartwright

23:30.quote: He loaded the player and turned on the viewer, his knees popping again as he squatted to set the cue to 2330.
23:30.author: David Foster Wallace

23:30.quote: He would catch the night bus for Casablanca, the one that left the beach at half past eleven.
23:30.book: 'The Dismissal', in Midnight Mass & Other Stories
23:30.author: Paul Bowles

23:30.quote: The Picton boat was due to leave at half-past eleven. It was a beautiful night, mild, starry, only when they got out of the cab and started to walk down the Old Wharf that jutted out into the harbour, a faint wind blowing off the water ruffled under Fenella's hat, and she put up her hand to keep it on.
23:30.author: Katherine Mansfield

23:30.quote: The ship's clock in the bar says half past eleven. Half past eleven is opening time. The hands of the clock have stayed still at half past eleven for fifty years.
23:30.author: Dylan Thomas

23:31.quote: It is twenty-nine minutes to midnight. Dr Narlikar's Nursing Home is running on a skeleton staff; there are many absentees, many employees who have preferred to celebrate the imminent birth of the nation, and will not assist tonight at the births of children.
23:31.author: Salman Rushdie

23:32.quote: """This is the evening. This is the night. It is New YearÂ´s Eve. In about twenty-eight minutes it will be midnight. I still have twenty-eight minutes left. I have to recollect my thoughts. At twelve oÂ´clock, I should be done thinking."" He looked at his father. ""Help those that are depressed and consider themselves lost in this world,"" he thought. ""Old fart."""
23:32.timeAlt: In about twenty-eight minutes it will be midnight.
23:32.author: Gerard Reve

23:32.quote: And then it started to rain and I got wet and I started shivering because I was cold. And then it was 11.32 pm and I heard voices of people walking along the street. And a voice said, 'I don't care whether you thought it was funny or not,' and it was a lady's voice.
23:32.book: The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-time
23:32.author: Mark Haddon

23:33.quote: We are on Colaba Causeway now, just for a moment, to reveal that at twenty-seven minutes to midnight, the police are hunting for a dangerous criminal. His name: Joseph D'Costa. The orderly is absent, has been absent for several days, from his work at the Nursing Home, from his room near the slaughterhouse, and from the life of a distraught virginal Mary
23:33.author: Salman Rushdie

23:34.quote: Eleven thirty-four. We stand on the sidewalk in front of Jean's apartment on the Upper East Side. Her doorman eyes us warily and fills me with a nameless dread, his gaze piercing me from the lobby. A curtain of stars, miles of them, are scattered, glowing, across the sky and their multitude humbles me, which I have a hard time tolerating. She shrugs and nods after I say something about forms of anxiety. It's as if her mind is having a hard time communicating with her mouth, as if she is searching for a rational analysis of who I am, which is, of course, an impossibility: there ... is ... no ... key.
23:34.author: Bret Easton Ellis

23:34.quote: Reacher retrieved his G36 from under the saloon bar window at eleven thirty-four precisely and set out to walk back on the road, which he figured would make the return trip faster.
23:34.author: Lee Child

23:35.quote: Then at eleven thirty-five the door at the rear of the hall opened and a police sergeant and three constables entered, ushered by Bagot.
23:35.author: Michael Innes

23:36.quote: Then Green knocks at the front door at 2336 - Gately has to Log the exact time and then it's his call whether to unlock the door.
23:36.author: David Foster Wallace
